shoes: Van Gogh painted several still lifes of shoes or boots during his Paris period.
Van Gogh has placed the shoes within a specific spatial context: namely, the red-tile floor of the Yellow House.
this "still life of old peasants' shoes" may have been those of Patience Escalier, whose portrait Van Gogh executed around the same time, late summer 1888.

palestinian: The Palestinian, upon the usurpation of his homeland, had to distinguish himself professionally and through his conduct in order for him to find his place in life.
Life for the Palestinians did not stop at any place in spite of its harshness, limitations and the arbitrariness of the laws.

Palestinian popular life persisted in the face of all kinds of oppression, whether in the areas which became under Israeli occupation within occupied Palestine (1948), or those areas occupied by Israel in 1967 (the West Bank & Gaza).
Thus, Palestinian living became subject to the changes which imposed a new pattern for the behavior and life of Palestinians, in the social, cultural, economic and political senses.
In effect, the Palestinian community remained cohesive and with a presence, maintaining its heritage and traditions.
The life of the Palestinian communities continued with its happy and sad moments- through a wedding or a new-born, or through the return of someone abroad.
The Palestinian toiled in all available arenas and in all professional specializations.
a new pattern of Palestinian life began to prevail inside the camp and outside of it.
aiding the Palestinian individual to re-evaluate what happened and, likewise, to ponder what could happen.

The Palestinian, upon the usurpation of his homeland, had to distinguish himself professionally and through his conduct in order for him to find his place in life. Life for the Palestinians did not stop at any place in spite of its harshness, limitations and the arbitrariness of the laws. Palestinian popular life persisted in the face of all kinds of oppression, whether in the areas which became under Israeli occupation within occupied Palestine (1948), or those areas occupied by Israel in 1967 (the West Bank & Gaza). Thus, Palestinian living became subject to the changes which imposed a new pattern for the behavior and life of Palestinians, in the social, cultural, economic and political senses. In effect, the Palestinian community remained cohesive and with a presence, maintaining its heritage and traditions. The life of the Palestinian communities continued with its happy and sad moments- through a wedding or a new-born, or through the return of someone abroad. The Palestinian toiled in all available arenas and in all professional specializations, aiding the Palestinian individual to re-evaluate what happened and, likewise, to ponder what could happen. A new pattern of Palestinian life began to prevail inside the camp and outside of it.

virgin: The Virgin is seated broadly and holds the half-naked infant on her lap.
The Virgin is seated broadly and holds the half-naked infant on her lap.
infant: holds the half-naked infant on her lap.

joseph: Joseph on the left is eclipsed by the two protagonists.
He sits at an angle facing them, on a seat lower than the Virgin's.
He looks up and focuses on a point somewhere outside the picture, as if reflecting on the words he has just read in the open book on his lap.
He holds his reading glasses absent-mindedly and is clearly lost in thought.
The portrayal of Joseph as a young and vigorous man, in contrast to the traditional elderly figure, is in line with the dictates of Counter-Reformationist principles.

edward iii: A series of eight paintings illustrating events from the reign of Edward III was commissioned from West by George III to decorate the Audience Chamber at Windsor Castle.
The series illustrates Edward III's campaign in northern France during the summer of 1346.

Edward III crossing the Somme is the first in the sequence and shows an incident preceding the Battle of Crécy, when the king was trying to cross the River Somme at Blanche Tache, near Abbeville, in order to escape the French army.
The king is on horseback just to the right of centre
Edward III had also been the founder of the Order of the Garter that is so closely associated with Windsor Castle.

A series of eight paintings illustrating events from the reign of Edward III was commissioned from West by George III to decorate the Audience Chamber at Windsor Castle. The series illustrates Edward III's campaign in northern France during the summer of 1346. Edward III crossing the Somme is the first in the sequence and shows an incident preceding the Battle of Crécy, when the king was trying to cross the River Somme at Blanche Tache, near Abbeville, in order to escape the French army. The king is on horseback just to the right of centre. Edward III had also been the founder of the Order of the Garter that is so closely associated with Windsor Castle.
english archers: dependent upon the skill of the English archers seen in the upper right of the composition.

The outcome of Edward III's encounter with a part of the French force under Godemar de Faye, like the Battle of Crécy itself, was dependent upon the skill of the English archers seen in the upper right of the composition.

armour: For the historical narrative the primary sources in English were an early translation of the Chronicles (1325-1400) of Jean Froissart and the History of England (1754-62) by David Hume.
